And he said that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He told everybody that at the beginning. I'm a counter puncher. You know, you hit, I'm going to hit you back twice as hard. So why is this some big mystery that he needs to go to counseling about, like to figure it out, or get like the answer for the secret sauce? This is how he feels. He feels this guy was disrespectful. Greg's right. It's old school. It's hey, this is your neighbor who was like, oh, I wouldn't tolerate that. I mean, I got this kid out. They should be appreciative. It's about like respect. So he's not going to take it from this guy. But he's not a very popular guy because, you know, Shaq.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, very unpopular.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Very unpopular.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.utterance: I think that's understood.

Do you think President Trump really wanted to say, hey, sorry about that. That's like his first ask? Like, could you crack down on North Korea, and also let my three guys go. A little bit of humility which is what the young man expressed last week. I mean, they all said, thank you, we're embarrassed, we're ashamed, and we've got a second shot, it's good. The other thing is that the president of the United States, he asked for them to be released, OK? Not -- there wasn't a big exposure for people who are being held by China for no reason at all, and are having their human rights violated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They've got special treatment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE

utterances.utterance: All right. After another U.S. border agent is killed, President Trump renews his call for the wall, next.

utterances.utterance: U.S. border agents put their lives in the line each day to protect our country. Tragically, one of them lost his life this weekend and another is hospitalized in serious condition after coming under attack in southwest Texas. Agent Rogelio Martinez was killed yesterday when responding to same kind of activity in the big bend area. His partner was hurt but survived. Details are still unclear. Authorities are hunting for the suspect. President Trump is vowing to seek out those responsible and bring them to justice. He also reiterated the need for the wall.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: As you heard, we lost a border patrol officer just yesterday. And another one was brutally beaten and badly, badly hurt. It looks like he'll make it but very, very badly hurt. And we talk about the wall -- we're going to have the wall. It's part of what we're doing. We need it. That's rough territory. That's where the drugs are coming in. A lot of things are happening along the border, the southern border. And we're going to straighten it out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Obviously, a very disturbing story, just the facts and circumstances still developing, you know, as we go to the news right now, Dana. But so you see the president, obviously, very upset about this, having a very genuine response. He's really had a -- even when he was campaigning, you know, reached out and had the support of the Border Patrol and the agents there, who have really had a very difficult path in terms of what they've been able to do, whether or not they've been understaffed. And coming under these attacks, where it's like, they literally don't know. They want to go home that night to their family.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So there's also an award that the Texas governor, Greg Abbott, has put out. It's $20,000 for any information that leads to the arrest of the -- basically, the people that ambushed our -- our not military, but our Border Patrol agents.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So then the question is, would a wall help in this particular area? I think that the wall, writ large, when they get down to business and start writing this legislation and having the discussion, I think it needs to be very clear that there's a lot of things that you can do on the security front, as the president has mentioned, a virtual wall in some places is going to be more practical, and it actually could help, probably, save lives of our Border Patrol agents before any actually structure can be built, because of just the terrain of that area. So I would just advise them, as they start to figure out how they're going to ask Congress for the money to appropriate, that yes, it will be possible to have an actual structure in certain places, but to take the win, if they get sort of more border security and virtual wall type of equipment down there.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So obviously, Jesse, it's still a very complex issue. There's a lot of resources that are needed. I mean, what are your thoughts? I think, you know, the more resources they have there, obviously, the better in terms of just, you know, men and women on the ground. To be able to patrol that area. I mean, a wall, some kind of physical obstruction, I think, makes it a little bit easier for their job in terms of making it more difficult for some of the menacing, you know, individuals that try to come over and violate the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It does. You know, when someone is killed with a gun, the left wants gun control. But when a Border Patrol agent is killed, you would think they would want border control. And all -- right now, assaults by illegal aliens on Border Patrol agents has hit an all-time high. Up 50 percent just from last year: 720 assaults on Border Patrol agents this year alone, not even counting September. And although border crossings are way down under President Trump -- I think they've only been a quarter million crossings last year. Last year was about a half a million.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It still shows that they're just pouring across, and the border is not secure. Now, I have a border wall update. The contracting process has begun. Eight prototypes have been built. The concrete is settling. They start the testing phase next week. Some you can see through, greater visibility up on our side. They average between 18 and 30 feet high. And right now $20 million have been appropriated. But now, the big funding is being tied up, potentially, in the DACA negotiations...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: ... which are going to come around Christmas.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, and just to -- Juan, just on a point that Jesse meant, the reason why this is also so dangerous is that these Border Patrol agents work in two-man teams, and a backup can be hours away. And they're confronted by large numbers, because they know the math on it, that you've got two guys, and then therefore, they can, you know, overcome them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. I mean, we have increased the number border agents astronomically. And we put in more of the type of equipment Dana was talking about: everything from drones to electronic surveillance. And all the rest. But I think in this instance, and it's very tragic. Because he wasn't even shot. He was beaten to death. So this is a really horrible personal type of attack where you have anger and violence involved. But I don't see why you would politicize it, then, as the basis for a wall when, as Jesse says, you know, crossings are down. In fact, they're a record down. And you've had 30 -- only 38 -- 38 -- agents involved in this kind of violence since '03. And one this year. So is this a new justification for building a wall that nobody in the U.S. wants and nobody in Mexico is willing to pay for? Apparently.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, 720 assaults on Border Patrol agents this year.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know what's going on with that, so I don't have the background, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The background is from the U.S. Border Patrol.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Very vulnerable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't doubt their statistics.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In terms -- in terms of people being killed, in terms of agents putting their lives on the line, as Kimberly was discussing, we've had one this year. It's just not a reason to say, "Oh, yes, we better rush to build. Change your opinion on the wall, America."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, we know it's not an easy job. They are the nation's bouncers, border agents. They are the first person facing the external challenges. This is the irony of this whole story. Politicians in sanctuary cities don't have to think about border agents. The actions of a border agent actually make the lives of the people in the sanctuary cities easier...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ... because they don't get to the sanctuary cities and cause more problems.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So that the border agent -- so if you took away these border agents because you felt it's mean, then your sanctuary cities will be more murderous than you could ever imagine. We need to drag this country into a contemporary understanding of the border. The border isn't just about immigration. It's national security. The advent of terror plus technology is going to make it possible for one person -- one person -- to sneak across with a drone and bioterror married together and create havoc that will make 9/11 look smaller. So we have to think about it in a bigger, more global way. It's not just about immigration. It's about our futures.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. We want to protect those that are serving our country and give them the resources that they need. And the numbers were woefully low, so now that's why we've had to hire more. More to be done. And Charles Manson is dead after more than half a century behind bars. The evil, murderous legacy he leaves behind next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: One of America's most notorious killers, dead. Charlie Manson breathed his last breath last night. He died of natural causes at age 83 after nearly half a century behind bars. Manson terrorized Los Angeles in 1969, when he committed his followers to kill actress Sharon Tate and six others. Geraldo Rivera interviewed the notorious cult killer in San Quentin back in the '80s.

utterances.speaker: CHARLES MANSON, LEADER OF CULT RESPONSIBLE FOR MASS MURDERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you could use the word devil or demons, or whatever you want to call it.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT-AT-LARGE
utterances.utterance: Mostly the devil in your world.

utterances.speaker: MANSON
utterances.utterance: OK, I'll play. I'll play. There's no game I can't play.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: People are saying you are the devil here.

utterances.speaker: MANSON
utterances.utterance: OK, I'll be the devil then.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You like that?

utterances.speaker: MANSON
utterances.utterance: I don't like or dislike nothing. I see everything as it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. I don't even know how to think of somebody who would create a cult and order that someone go in and kill. And I mean, it wasn't just killing. It was violent, horrible stabbings and the like, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was the first identity politics terrorist. The point was to kill a bunch of white people and pin it on the Black Panthers. That's why they did that. That's why they wrote the stuff in blood on the walls. He was trying to create an apocalyptic race war. The less said about him, though, is probably the better. The media devotes way too much ink on -- on the irrational fascination with evil. We see hours of forensic files in all these special documentaries. Meanwhile, thousands of good people die every single day. They lead quiet, noble lives. The little old lady who slips in a bathtub that you don't ever hear about. The guy who gets hit by a bus, trying to meet his family. Della Reese died today. A great woman.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wonderful. "Touched By An Angel."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, but this -- this touched by a devil here gets more ink than being "Touched By An Angel."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know -- so let me talk to my California girl.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So what did you think of him and the idea there's now one of the people who participated in these murders, Leslie Van Houten, she's 69. But she had been pardoned. It's going to get up to the governor to decide whether or not to let her out. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't think she should get out. I don't think anybody associated with this, and participated as an accessory and accomplice with respect to these horrific murders should ever get out. In fact, the man who trained me at at the Los Angeles district attorney's office, Stephen Kay, was one of the Manson prosecutors in these murders, in the Tate-LaBianca murders, along with Vincent Bugliosi. And he has faithfully, every time, been summoned and gone to fight on behalf of these victims, prevent these animals from being released. That history and time should not forget the misdeeds and the horrific crimes that they committed. You know, he spent so much time with him and said he's just an unbelievably horrifically evil individual that you could not even possibly imagine. And so I don't think the right message is to pardon or to let people out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That is not the right form to show the deterrent to people to commit a crime like this. I'm so happy that this man died in -- you know, in jail. And was never released. And it was not easy, believe me. They had to fight hard to be able to keep him in, if you can imagine that. Because otherwise, you would never think in a million years, like, anyone would have a quarrel with keeping somebody like this in. You know?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Jesse, in reading about this, some things just jumped out at me. One is, he went -- I mean, he was born from a prostitute, doesn't know his father, takes his stepfather's name. Then you get into a situation where he is hanging around with Dennis Wilson of The Beach Boys and Terry Melcher, who was a record producer. He thinks he has musical talent, doesn't get picked up. And that's why he goes to that house where Roman Polanski lived with Sharon Tate. And by the way, he was a big fan of Dale Carnegie. That's how he learned the principles that he used to create the cult. It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's a mentally ill maniac. He said -- this is a killer quote -- "I am crime." Geraldo, you know, hats off to him, got him on tape right there in prison saying, "I am the devil." I think to what Greg was saying, I think it's good sometimes when you spotlight evil. Not all the time but just to look evil in the eye to see what it is so you really know what good is. And it also goes to show a mind control, the amount of mind control he had over these cult followers. And you're always, you know, taking these psychedelic drugs. The power he had over them was just phenomenal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And over so many women...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't knock the drugs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... like Greg said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And they were mostly women, and that's always been an interesting element to cults. Is that women are attracted to -- some women who are naive or gullible are attracted to that kind of thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, so Dana, I have a challenge for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're a sweet soul. And I wonder if you can tell us what you would say nice about someone like this who just died.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No way. Don't take the challenge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can't do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Good food for maggots.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, maybe, I guess. But I would say that spotlighting this evil, when I was a kid. And he scared the crap out of me. I was terrified of cults, of mind control and of the evil. And I think that at least knowing about it helped me, you know, at least navigate a little bit more, of all that stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Agreed. Me, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Great point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Love him or hate him, somebody must've been the first person to take a selfie. Well, guess what? Paris Hilton thinks it's her. But there's lots of photographic evidence that seems to prove otherwise. Hmm. Next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A very important question for you now. Who do you think invented the selfie? Paris Hilton has set the Internet on fire after claiming she and Britney Spears did 11 years ago, posting these pictures from 2006. Many are taking issue with that claim. Here's some photographic evidence. Thelma and Louise took one back in the '90s. Colin Powell posted this snapshot from the 1950s. But perhaps the oldest existing selfie is from the 1800s taken by a photographer named Robert Cornelius. And that is in Jesse's home town of Philadelphia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And his collar's up. I love that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Stylish. Maybe you're, like...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stylish guy, that Cornelius.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... reincarnated from him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I hope so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like the name Cornelius.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do, too. Now I learned how to take a selfie. I was watching E! one time. And Kim Kardashian said you're supposed to hold it high and at a 45-degree angle. Not in front. High and at a 45 degree. High and at a 45 degree. Like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Story of my life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everybody, pay attention.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Did she figure that out?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think? I mean, Paris Hilton, basically, she doesn't - - might as well claim it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: By the way, I mean, kind of she was the one that started it all up again, I mean, no disrespect to your...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Cornelius.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... doppelganger Cornelius there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I hope I'm in the will. But she was the one doing it all the time and people started, really, like this incessant thing with selfies. And then remember the selfie stick?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Juan has one of those. Right, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, in fact, that was going to be my thing, because you just -- you walk down the street in New York, right, and especially now with the holiday season, these people have these sticks. They're wielding them. They don't have any consciousness of somebody else.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You've got to have respect if you have the stick.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: See, Juan's old-school.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, let's be honest here. Paris Hilton did not invent the selfie. She invented the sex tape. If we don't -- we probably don't remember that, because every day now we have a scandal. So we used to only get one scandal a year. Remember? It would be one scandal. And that was one of them. Now every day we have an avalanche of impropriety. The difference is it's not Paris Hilton. It's Charlie Rose and -- and Al Franken. I mean, just thinking of that makes me nauseous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You long for the days of the Paris Hilton scandals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ... for the days when the people with sex scandals...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, well, Glenn Thrush.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And Glenn Thrush.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't forget.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. They're all creepy men.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Tune in tomorrow morning when we'll have 20 more to talk about. All right. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, we're getting breaking news. President Trump is going to issue a pardon tomorrow, just getting this in. It's of a turkey, though. So the annual White House Thanksgiving turkey pardon will be tomorrow. You guys didn't like that joke?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Papadopoulos and Manafort are the names. Just kidding. The names are Wishbone and Drumstick. And they're actually putting them up in a little hotel here. And they're going to be pardoned in the Rose Garden tomorrow. And you can go to the White House Twitter feed and vote on who do you think should be pardoned, Wishbone or Drumstick. Cast your votes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. So there's an Indian man named Souschous (ph)...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Sushi?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... Dixit (ph)? OK?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, very good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, actually, his name is pronounced something else, but I can't say it. He has declared himself king. He has -- drove from India to between Egypt and Sudan. There's this 800-square-mile area known as Biertawil (ph), and it is unclaimed land. And basically, if you throw some seeds on the ground, you can declare yourself king. And so other people have tried it but nobody has been able to persevere. He's saying that he will and that he will write an email to the United Nations about his kingdom. He has created a Facebook page and is seeking people to invest.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You can actually invest in the kingdom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm there. I'm going to do that. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, well, I have a very special "One More Thing." Because Ronan, my little Ro-Dog, was in the championship football game this weekend with the Titans, and they crushed it. There's Ronan running. Great athlete. God bless him. And he's there also, his dad and his godfather. And then he scored the first touchdown of the championship game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, great.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And I was very excited with his cousin Leo there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is that touch?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's flag football. See, there he is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Flag football. Very good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Good sport.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Excellent cinematography, I might add.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Congrats, Ronan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Good job, Ronan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Juanzo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kaboom! The 25-year-old Georgia Dome was imploded this morning. It took 5,000 pounds of explosives to blow up the 71,000-seat stadium in only 15 seconds.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You probably know it as the longtime home of the Atlanta Falcons, the NFL team. But you know what? It also housed two Super Bowls, the 1996 Olympic basketball tournament, three Final Four NCAA basketball tournaments. And now replaced by the $1.6 billion Mercedes-Benz Stadium right next door. The new ballpark, fit for a king with a retractable roof and a giant steel sculpture of a falcon. I think we build stadiums, no longer cathedrals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is so true, Juan. And you know what? I am going to elaborate further on what you just talked about. The Weather Channel had actually covered this event, this implosion of the Georgia Dome. And they actually had a camera set up to watch it. So have you ever been here before? So they've got the camera set up. Everything is good to watch the implosion. It's going to be great. Everything is perfect, and then as it's about to happen. You've got your three, your two, your one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The bus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The bus pulls up, blocks it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I heard that beep.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bus driver has got the best -- he's got the best view. And the guy -- and the Weather Channel guy, you can hear, is actually swearing. By the way, since when did the Weather Channel cover implosions of buildings?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But how nuts is that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How about the Market bus? It's like...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's -- yes, the guy has no idea. He's just doing his job.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's got to get the tape from the people that were on the sidewalk. That's the thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why do we like it when buildings implode?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Man, it's so much fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I love it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They do it so that it just falls directly down and nobody gets hurt.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You've got to see when they do that in Los Angeles, and it's like some of the old hotels, and they build new ones and they detonate them. It's pretty cool.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? They had to put up a huge wall, though, like a blanket...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... to keep the old stadium from damaging the new stadium.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought walls didn't work, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. For you, it would have been Mexicans, right?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Ohh!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Ohh!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ohh!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just want to hear you say "kaboom" one more time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I like it. Did you like that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Say it one more time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Guess what? Kaboom.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kaboom!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Guess what? Kaboom. I'm going to keep saying it. Anyway, we've got about 30 seconds left. I thought that Kimberly's son did quite a job on that football game.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He did.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What are you eating for dinner tonight?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I -- well, I had Chinese food this afternoon, so I can't have Chinese food again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, you can't double.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Please don't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Never double dip on Chinese food.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Never set -- never set your DVRs. Never do it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report." Bret, over to you. Bretso.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hey, Bretto. Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
